content.description: Start with a few moves to get up the roof. "Zig" or traverse to the left and move up to the face. "Zag" right around an arete and up a gradually climbing set of holds well marked with chalk. Move up and "zig" back left to the anchor.
content.protection: Pair of eyebolts on top of the rock. Use the anchor that will drop a rope closest to the start of the climb. We find it convenient to belay from the bottom of the pipe for climbs on this anchor, since it leaves the trail clear for foot and bike traffic.
content.location: Start under the most overhanging section of rock on the main face of the upper rock, standing on the pipe, about 10 feet to the climber's left of the manhole cover. Get lowered off on toprope, or else top out and walk down trails to either side.

content.description: Eliminate traverse problem, trending uphill, with surprisingly consistent little crimps and interesting footwork. Start on the uphill portion of Livezey rock, just right of the crack/flake system for the rightmost toprope climb. Crack/flake is off, for full effect on the start. Move vertically a few moves (but not to the top of the face) then traverse right until the rock ends in the hillside. Recommend 2 crash pads, not because of the height but because there's a big log and a rock in the landing that you need to protect.Â

Start on "anchor 1," the bolt and tree combo on steep, shorter left side of the rock. 

  Jug haul up the arete to the top. 

  Route has been used for decades but is unnamed.  

  My guess is 5.6 or 5.7. Big holds, straightforward, but steep and occasionally committing. 

  Starting further left gives an easier start. 

  Keeping just left of the arete gives a harder start. 

  Eliminating holds yields tougher variations.
content.protection: Bolt and tree, padding as anchor will extend over rock edges.

content.description: Finger crack left of Regular. This route name is from Curt Harler's "Climb Pennsylvania" book, which is the only place I've seen it used so far.
Logged by Jim Fiore on theCrag.com. I'm not sure where he got the name, or the specific line or eliminate it is.
Also there is a variation off the 5.8 called Sandy's Route done by a great Gunks climber, Sandy Stewart.

It starts directly in front of the man hole, the same place as the nine but break left. Climb through the small roof and go up the face. Stay well right of the arete. There are some small horizontals and side pulls up the bulge. I think it's on the harder side of 5.11 - a solid V3 boulder problem.

This name was noted by Jim Fiore elsewhere online. 

  "I think this is the right side of the bulge, up the ramp. Maybe the 3rd route from right?" -airingout
Start with a few moves to get up the roof. Climb the arete up, and slightly left, to the top of the rock. The last move is a long one.
content.protection: Start under the most overhanging section of rock on the main face of the upper rock, standing on the pipe, about 10 feet to the climber's left of the manhole cover. Get lowered off on toprope, or else top out and walk down trails to either side.
content.location: Pair of eyebolts on top of the rock. Use the anchor that will drop a rope closest to the start of the climb. We find it convenient to belay from the bottom of the pipe for climbs on this anchor, since it leaves the trail clear for foot and bike traffic.

content.description: Far side of left face. From Dave R.: "Yes, the crack to the left, called Das Fraulein, is an easier way to finish, but if you do it, hang your top route on bolt anchors directly above it to avoid a pendulum. "
Starts in front of the manhole cover. Follows a line just left of straight up to the anchor.
content.protection: Old but solid anchor bolts on top.
content.location: On the mostly vertical right side of main face, directly in front of the manhole cover.

content.description: Starts in front of the manhole cover. Follows a line mostly straight up to the anchor.
content.protection: Old but solid anchor bolts on top.
content.location: On the mostly vertical right side of main face, directly in front of the manhole cover.

content.description: Starts in front of the manhole cover. Follows a low easy ledge up and to the right, then small ledges up to the left, and up to the ledge with the plaque. From the ledge, up to the top.
content.protection: Old but solid anchor bolts on top.
content.location: On the mostly vertical right side of main face, directly in front of the manhole cover.
